prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Polarization PanSTARRS230
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation of comet C/2012 K1 PanSTARRS at 230 GHz including full polarization

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Simulations We generated model images to run through the CASA ALMA simulator to determine feasibility of our proposed observations. The nominal comet model has 3 components: the nucleus is a point source with flux estimated using a Standard Thermal Model (for radius 2 km, Fernandez et al. 2012); the coma is cylindrically symmetric with surface brightness of a freely expanding dust with constant production rate (projected to 1/ρ distribution on the sky; dust column Afρ=20 cm, cf. A’Hearn et al. 1995); and the trail is one-sided along the orbit with a Gaussian vertical profile and cutoff leading the comet (optical depth of 5x10-8, Reach, Kelley, Sykes 2007). The nuclear flux was estimated with a Standard Thermal Model at each ALMA frequency. At 345 GHz the predicted fluxes are 28 mJy from the coma and 0.5 mJy from the nucleus. The optimal frequency for cometary dust observations was determined using the ALMA time estimator; the signal/noise is highest at 345 GHz, closely followed by 230 GHz. Frequencies Figure 3 in the science justification shows the nominal model and the simulated ALMA observation with the 12m antennas (Cycle 1 availability) at 345 GHz. The model images clearly show the coma dominates the image, while the trail is relatively faint. The coma and nucleus are of comparable flux density for R~1 km and Afρ~1 cm, which are typical of comets. Higher frequencies improve nucleus/coma separation (because nuclei are warmer due to their ability to maintain a day/night temperature gradient) but are more challenging for ALMA and we believe should await a future Cycle. For this proposal we chose the 345 and 230 GHz, where the sensitivity is high and a measurement of the spectral index can be obtained from the 230/345 GHz ratio. A moderate array configuration such as C232-2 would detect most of the coma flux: comparing the coma model to the synthesized simulation, we recover 52% of the coma flux using the 12m array alone (97% if the ACA were included, for reference), which well utilizes the capabilities of the facility to discern the nucleus (requiring some long baselines) and the coma flux. Spatial distribution and Sensitivity The 1-hour simulation shows that ALMA would cleanly detect the nominal model coma (max/rms=100). A separate simulation with the coma set to zero shows the nucleus is also strongly detected on its own (max/rms=67). The nominal model debris trail would not be detected so we do not discuss it further here. Based on this simulation experiment we estimate that we are sensitive to coma due to dust with Afρ>1 cm and to nuclei with flux density Fn>0.8 mJy (both numbers at signal-to-noise 10). For comparison the ALMA time estimator yields a main array sensitivity of 0.7 mJy at 10σ, in excellent agreement with the simulations., and the Cycle 2 Observing Tool indicates 1.1 hour observations are needed at 345 GHz and 43 minutes at 230 GHz, very close to the nominal 1-hour simulation we ran.
Polarization The full-polarization mode is selected, so that the linear (and potentially, circular) polarization can be measured. For this reason, 3 hour tracks are requested, somewhat longer than the ~1-hour nominal track estimated based solely on total flux S/N. The predicted polarization is at the ~10% level, based on the measured polarization of interstellar dust grains. This in principle requires S/N=100, which is achieved with the nominal model or, with smoothing, even a factor of 3 fainter comet.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: By observing the thermal emission from 3 comets, we will measure the mass of dust they produce. Millimeter- and submillimeter observations constrain the total mass of dust because they are relatively insensitive to dust temperature and can sample the largest particles that bear the most mass. Large dust particles and possibly small meteorids also may produce significant linearly polarized emission, a measurement of which has not yet been reported and which ALMA is capable of performing.
